messages.text: In a single year, temperature jumps around from month to month with no particular pattern.
The average global temperature jumps around from year to year. It's hard to see any pattern when looking at only a handful of years.
Several decades of temperature records don't always show whether the planet is warming or cooling.
You can begin to see patterns of climate change can be seen when looking at 40 years of records or more.
When viewing over a century of global temperature records, a clear warming trend is observed.

annotations.text: From 1910 to the 1940s, there is some warming from both human CO2 emissions and natural factors.
Warming trend peaks, slight cooling begins.
From the 1940s to 1975, aerosols from pollution and volcanic eruptions cool planet slightly.
Warming starts to accelerate, driven by human CO₂ emissions.
Rate of warming increases to 0.3°C (0.5°F) per decade.
Sea level rise accelerates to 30 millimeters (1.10 inches) per decade, doubling 1901-1990 mean.
A strong El Niño event boosts warming from greenhouse gases, breaking 118 years of heat records.
A historic heat wave in Europe kills 70,000 people.
Lowest recorded Arctic sea ice extent in satellite record.
